per_prompt_data.prompt: What happened in the incident of the Hindenburg disaster? Keep your response short with no more than 200 words.
per_prompt_data.side2_response:
The Hindenburg disaster occurred on May 6, 1937, when the German passenger airship LZ 129 Hindenburg caught fire and was destroyed during its landing approach at Lakehurst Naval Air Station in New Jersey, USA.

The rigid airship, filled with highly flammable hydrogen, was nearing its mooring mast after a transatlantic flight when flames suddenly erupted near its tail fin. The fire rapidly engulfed the entire airship, which then crashed to the ground in a little over 30 seconds. Of the 97 people on board (36 passengers, 61 crew), 35 died, along with one ground crewman.

The exact cause remains debated, but theories include a spark igniting leaking hydrogen, possibly from a static discharge or lightning. The catastrophe was extensively filmed and photographed, effectively ending the era of large passenger airships.

per_prompt_data.prompt: Can you tell me about the European Investment Bank? Keep your response short with no more than 200 words.
per_prompt_data.side2_response:
The European Investment Bank (EIB) is the EU’s long-term lending institution, owned by the 27 EU member states. Founded in 1958 under the Treaty of Rome, it provides financing for projects that support EU policy goals, such as climate action, innovation, infrastructure, and social cohesion.

The EIB raises funds on capital markets (issuing bonds) and lends at favorable rates to both public and private sectors. Key priorities include:
- Climate & sustainability (aiming for 50%+ of financing to support green projects by 2025).
- Innovation & SMEs (via loans, guarantees, and venture capital).
- Cohesion & development (reducing regional disparities).
- Digital transformation and strategic autonomy (e.g., semiconductors, energy security).

It operates globally but focuses on Europe, with special initiatives like the InvestEU program (mobilizing €372 billion in investment by 2027). The EIB also manages the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) and supports Ukraine’s reconstruction.

Headquartered in Luxembourg, it works closely with the European Commission and other EU bodies. The EIB Group includes the European Investment Fund (EIF), which specializes in SME support.

Criticisms include bureaucracy and debates over fossil fuel financing (though it ended most such projects in 2021). The EIB remains a key player in EU economic resilience.

per_prompt_data.prompt: Who is René Laennec? Keep your response short with no more than 200 words.
per_prompt_data.side2_response: René Laennec (1781–1826) was a French physician renowned for inventing the stethoscope in 1816. He revolutionized the practice of medicine by introducing **auscultation**, the act of listening to internal sounds of the body, as a diagnostic tool. Before Laennec’s invention, doctors often had to place their ear directly on a patient’s chest, which was both ineffective and inappropriate. Laennec’s stethoscope—a wooden tube—improved diagnostic accuracy for diseases such as tuberculosis and pneumonia. His work laid the foundation for modern physical examination techniques and his contributions earned him recognition as the "father of clinical auscultation."

per_prompt_data.prompt: What is the video game "League of Legends"? Keep your response short with no more than 200 words.
per_prompt_data.side2_response:
**League of Legends** (LoL) is a free-to-play multiplayer online battle arena (MOBA) video game developed and published by Riot Games. Released in 2009 for Microsoft Windows and macOS, it quickly grew into one of the most popular eSports titles worldwide.

In League of Legends, two teams of five players each compete on a map called Summoner’s Rift. Each player controls a champion, a unique character with distinct abilities. The objective is to destroy the opposing team’s Nexus, located in their base, while defending your own. Players must work together to defeat enemies, complete objectives, and earn gold and experience to grow stronger.

League of Legends is renowned for its strategic depth, frequent updates, and diverse champion roster—now exceeding 160 characters. It has a massive fanbase and hosts professional leagues and tournaments, including the prestigious annual World Championship. The game’s success has also led to spin-offs, music, animation, and other multimedia projects.

per_prompt_data.prompt: Who is Benedict Cumberbatch? Keep your response short with no more than 200 words.
per_prompt_data.side2_response: Benedict Cumberbatch is a British actor known for his versatile performances in film, television, and theater. He gained international fame for portraying Sherlock Holmes in the BBC series "Sherlock." Cumberbatch has also appeared in major movies such as "The Imitation Game" (as Alan Turing), "Doctor Strange" in the Marvel Cinematic Universe, and "The Power of the Dog." Renowned for his deep voice and expressive acting, he has received numerous awards and nominations, including Emmy and BAFTA awards. Cumberbatch trained at the London Academy of Music and Dramatic Art and has also performed on stage in acclaimed productions like "Hamlet."

per_prompt_data.prompt: Who is Susan Wojcicki and what is her role at YouTube? Keep your response short with no more than 200 words.
per_prompt_data.side2_response: Susan Wojcicki is an American business executive who served as the CEO of YouTube from February 2014 to February 2023. Before becoming YouTube’s CEO, she was involved in Google’s early development, working as its first marketing manager and later leading the company’s advertising products. As CEO, Wojcicki oversaw YouTube’s growth into the world’s largest online video platform, introducing new features, content moderation policies, and revenue streams for creators. In February 2023, Wojcicki stepped down from her role as CEO and was succeeded by Neal Mohan.

per_prompt_data.prompt: What can you tell me about Lake Baikal? Keep your response short with no more than 200 words.
per_prompt_data.side2_response:
Lake Baikal, located in Siberia, Russia, is the world's deepest and oldest freshwater lake. It reaches depths of about 1,642 meters (5,387 feet) and is estimated to be around 25 million years old. Baikal holds roughly 20% of the planet’s unfrozen surface freshwater—more than any other lake.

The lake is renowned for its unique biodiversity. It’s home to over 3,700 plant and animal species, most notably the Baikal seal (nerpa), the world’s only freshwater seal. Lake Baikal’s crystal-clear water and dramatic landscapes attract eco-tourism and scientific interest.

Baikal is a UNESCO World Heritage Site, celebrated not just for its ecological importance, but also for its cultural significance to local Indigenous peoples and Russian history. Threats to its ecosystem, including industrial pollution and climate change, have prompted global calls for conservation.

per_prompt_data.prompt: Who is Craig Venter? Keep your response short with no more than 200 words.
per_prompt_data.side2_response: Craig Venter is an influential American biotechnologist, geneticist, and entrepreneur known for his pioneering work in sequencing the human genome. He played a key role in the Human Genome Project and founded Celera Genomics, which used shotgun sequencing methods to accelerate genome mapping. Venter is also the founder of several biotechnology companies, including the J. Craig Venter Institute. In 2010, his team created the first synthetic bacterial cell, marking a milestone in synthetic biology. His research has significantly advanced genomics, personalized medicine, and synthetic life.

per_prompt_data.prompt: Who is lawyer Alan Dershowitz? Keep your response short with no more than 200 words.
per_prompt_data.side2_response:
Alan Dershowitz is an American lawyer, legal scholar, and retired Harvard Law School professor. Born in 1938, he became Harvard's youngest full professor of law at age 28. Dershowitz is a prominent appellate lawyer and has participated in several high-profile legal cases, defending clients such as O.J. Simpson, Claus von Bülow, Jeffrey Epstein, and Donald Trump. He is known for his expertise in U.S. constitutional and criminal law.

Dershowitz is also a prolific author and media commentator, frequently writing and speaking on issues like civil liberties, free speech, and the Israeli–Palestinian conflict. His career is marked by both widespread influence and controversy, as he often takes on polarizing clients and causes. While respected for his legal acumen, Dershowitz has also faced criticism for some of his clients and positions, particularly in relation to his defenses of unpopular or controversial figures.

per_prompt_data.prompt: What is the Altamira Cave? Keep your response short with no more than 200 words.
per_prompt_data.side2_response:
The Altamira Cave is a renowned prehistoric cave located near Santillana del Mar in northern Spain. Discovered in 1868, it is famous for its stunning Upper Paleolithic cave paintings, primarily created by the Magdalenian people around 36,000 to 13,000 years ago. The artwork depicts bison, horses, deer, and handprints, showcasing sophisticated use of natural pigments and shading techniques.

Often called the "Sistine Chapel of Prehistoric Art," Altamira provides valuable insight into early human life, culture, and artistic expression. Due to concerns about preservation, the original cave is closed to the public, but a replica exists nearby for visitors. In 1985, Altamira Cave was designated a UNESCO World Heritage Site, emphasizing its importance as one of the world’s most significant archaeological and artistic sites.

per_prompt_data.prompt: Who is the guitarist "Carlos Santana"? Keep your response short with no more than 200 words.
per_prompt_data.side2_response: Carlos Santana is a renowned Mexican-American guitarist, best known as the leader of the band Santana. He gained fame in the late 1960s and early 1970s with his band’s unique blend of rock, Latin music, blues, and jazz. Santana’s guitar style is recognized for its melodic, sustained notes and Latin-infused rhythms. He achieved major popularity after an electrifying performance at Woodstock in 1969 and hits like “Black Magic Woman,” “Oye Como Va,” and “Smooth.” Over his career, Santana has won multiple Grammy Awards and is widely respected as one of the greatest guitarists in rock history.

per_prompt_data.prompt: What can you tell me about the opening of the first McDonald's restaurant? Keep your response short with no more than 200 words.
per_prompt_data.side2_response:
The first McDonald's restaurant was opened by brothers Richard and Maurice McDonald in San Bernardino, California, on April 15, 1940. Initially, it was a drive-in called "McDonald's Bar-B-Q," featuring 25 items on the menu. In 1948, the brothers revamped the business, introducing the innovative "Speedee Service System," which focused on fast, efficient preparation of a small menu of burgers, fries, and drinks.

This model emphasized quick service, affordability, and consistency, shaping the future of fast food. In 1954, Ray Kroc, a milkshake machine salesman, visited the restaurant and was impressed by its operation. He partnered with the McDonald brothers in 1955, opening the first franchised McDonald's in Des Plaines, Illinois, and later bought out the brothers. Kroc’s vision and expansion strategies turned McDonald's into the world’s largest fast food chain.

per_prompt_data.prompt: Who is John Negroponte in relation to U.S. foreign policy? Keep your response short with no more than 200 words.
per_prompt_data.side2_response: John Negroponte is a veteran American diplomat with significant influence on U.S. foreign policy, especially from the 1980s through the early 2000s. He served as U.S. Ambassador to several countries, notably Honduras (1981–1985) during the Reagan administration, where he played a key role in supporting Contra rebels against Nicaragua's Sandinista government. Negroponte was also U.S. Ambassador to the United Nations (2001–2004) and Iraq (2004–2005) under President George W. Bush, overseeing diplomatic strategy during major conflicts. In 2005, he became the first Director of National Intelligence, coordinating U.S. intelligence agencies post-9/11. His career is marked by controversial involvements in Central America and pivotal roles in the War on Terror, making him a significant, if sometimes contentious, figure in shaping late 20th and early 21st-century U.S. foreign policy.

per_prompt_data.prompt: Who is the cybersecurity researcher Dan Kaminsky? Keep your response short with no more than 200 words.
per_prompt_data.side2_response:
Dan Kaminsky (1979–2021) was a pioneering American cybersecurity researcher renowned for uncovering critical vulnerabilities in the internet’s core infrastructure. He gained global recognition in 2008 for discovering and helping remediate a major flaw in the Domain Name System (DNS), which, if exploited, could have allowed hackers to redirect internet traffic or conduct massive phishing attacks. Kaminsky worked to coordinate a secret, industry-wide fix before publicly disclosing the issue.

Known as a “hacker’s hacker,” Kaminsky frequently spoke at cybersecurity conferences like Black Hat and DEF CON. He advocated for Internet security, accessibility, and privacy, and contributed to open source projects. Kaminsky also worked on projects to help the hearing-impaired and was an advisor to companies and the U.S. government.

His ethical approach and collaborative style made him a respected figure in both security research and the broader tech community.

per_prompt_data.prompt: Who is Linus Torvalds? Keep your response short with no more than 200 words.
per_prompt_data.side2_response:
Linus Torvalds is a Finnish-American software engineer best known for creating the Linux operating system kernel in 1991. Born in Helsinki, Finland, in 1969, Torvalds released Linux as open-source software, allowing worldwide collaboration and development. This kernel became the foundation for many popular operating systems, including Android and countless distributions of Linux used on servers, desktops, and embedded systems globally.

Torvalds is also recognized for creating Git, a powerful version control system widely used in software development. Over the years, he has received numerous awards for his contributions to technology, including the Millennium Technology Prize. Today, Torvalds continues to oversee the development of the Linux kernel, guiding a large international community of contributors.

per_prompt_data.prompt: What was the ethical controversy surrounding the Blackwater shootings in Iraq in 2007? Keep your response short with no more than 200 words.
per_prompt_data.side2_response:
The ethical controversy surrounding the 2007 Blackwater shootings in Iraq centers on a deadly incident in Baghdad’s Nisour Square, where Blackwater security contractors opened fire on Iraqi civilians, killing 17 people and wounding 20 others. Critics argue the shootings were unprovoked and constituted an excessive and disproportionate use of force, as many victims were unarmed.

The controversy highlighted issues of accountability, as private military contractors operated under ambiguous legal jurisdiction and were initially shielded from prosecution under Iraqi law. Additionally, the incident raised questions about oversight, the blurred lines between military and contractor roles, and the broader ethical implications of using private firms in conflict zones. The U.S. government’s initial response—evacuating the contractors from Iraq and delaying legal action—sparked outrage among Iraqis and human rights groups, who saw it as a lack of justice and respect for local sovereignty.

Ultimately, the Blackwater shootings symbolized the dangers of privatized warfare and undermined trust in U.S. operations in Iraq, fueling anti-American sentiment and debates about the moral and legal responsibilities of contractors in conflict zones.

per_prompt_data.prompt: What is known about the exoplanet called Proxima Centauri b? Keep your response short with no more than 200 words.
per_prompt_data.side2_response:
**Proxima Centauri b** is an exoplanet orbiting Proxima Centauri, the closest star to the Sun, about 4.24 light-years away. Discovered in 2016, Proxima b is at least 1.17 Earth masses and orbits within the star’s habitable zone, where temperatures could allow liquid water on its surface.

The planet orbits its star every 11.2 days at about 0.0485 AU (7 million km). Proxima Centauri is a red dwarf, so its habitable zone is much closer than our own. Proxima b is likely tidally locked, with one side always facing its star. The planet receives about 65% of the energy Earth gets from the Sun.

Major uncertainties exist regarding its atmosphere, composition, and actual habitability. Proxima Centauri regularly emits stellar flares, which may erode any atmosphere and pose challenges to life as we know it.

Proxima b was detected using the radial velocity method; no transits have been observed. Its proximity to Earth makes it a prime target for future studies and potential interstellar probe missions, but current instruments cannot yet confirm if it has an atmosphere, water, or life.

per_prompt_data.prompt: What can you tell me about the Serengeti National Park? Keep your response short with no more than 200 words.
per_prompt_data.side2_response: Serengeti National Park, located in northern Tanzania, is one of Africa’s most renowned wildlife reserves. Established in 1951 and covering about 14,750 square kilometers (5,700 sq miles), it's famed for its vast savannahs and extraordinary biodiversity. The park is best known for hosting the annual Great Migration, where over 1.5 million wildebeest, along with hundreds of thousands of zebras and gazelles, move in search of fresh grazing, attracting predators like lions, crocodiles, and hyenas. The Serengeti is also home to the Big Five (lion, leopard, elephant, buffalo, and rhino), over 500 bird species, and a wide variety of other mammals and reptiles. It's designated as a UNESCO World Heritage Site due to its ecological significance and breathtaking landscapes, ranging from open plains to woodlands and riverine forests. The park offers excellent game viewing, particularly between June and October. Sustainable tourism is emphasized, protecting its unique ecosystem and supporting local communities.

per_prompt_data.prompt: Can you tell me about the RadioAstron space radio telescope? Keep your response short with no more than 200 words.
per_prompt_data.side2_response:
RadioAstron was a Russian space radio telescope launched in 2011 as part of the Spektr-R mission. Operated by the Russian Astro Space Center, it featured a 10-meter radio dish and operated in orbit around Earth. RadioAstron's unique capability was performing space very-long-baseline interferometry (VLBI) by combining its observations with those from ground-based radio telescopes around the world. This collaboration allowed the array to achieve angular resolutions far exceeding any single telescope, up to microarcsecond levels.

RadioAstron observed cosmic phenomena such as quasars, pulsars, and the structure of active galactic nuclei (AGN), expanding our understanding of the universe’s most energetic processes. The telescope operated at frequencies from 330 MHz to 22 GHz. The mission ended in January 2019, after nearly eight years of observations, due to loss of contact with the spacecraft. Despite this, RadioAstron provided valuable scientific data and set records for the longest interferometric baselines ever achieved.

per_prompt_data.prompt: What is the Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) pandemic? Keep your response short with no more than 200 words.
per_prompt_data.side2_response:
The Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) pandemic refers to the global spread and impact of HIV, a virus that attacks the immune system and can lead to acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS). Since the early 1980s, HIV has infected over 75 million people worldwide, causing more than 32 million deaths. The virus is mainly spread through unprotected sex, sharing needles, and from mother to child during childbirth or breastfeeding. 

While antiretroviral therapy (ART) allows people with HIV to live longer, healthier lives, HIV remains a significant health challenge, especially in sub-Saharan Africa, which bears the highest burden. Prevention efforts include safe sex education, needle-exchange programs, and treatment as prevention. Stigma, lack of access to healthcare, and misinformation continue to hinder global control of the pandemic. Although there is currently no cure or vaccine, ongoing research and advancements in treatment and prevention are helping reduce new infections and improve the quality of life for people living with HIV.
